prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
In this science goal, we propose observations of [CII] 158um emission from a galaxy with a spectroscopic redshift of z=5.79. We center the lowest baseband in the lower sideband on the expected frequency of [CII] (279.9 GHz), and place the other three basebands spanning higher frequencies, to probe the rest-frame far-infrared emission (281.9, 291.9 and 293.9 GHz, which spans rest-frame 150-157 um). In the immediate objective portion of the proposal, we discussed how we arrived at our expected [CII] flux density of 2.91 mJy, assuming a line FWHM of 150 km/s.
We use the 1.875 GHz bandwidth for the baseband observing [CII], and the widest bandwidth (2 GHz) setting for the continuum basebands, to probe as much of the continuum as possible. We assume a point source, as these galaxies have sizes of ~0.2-0.3".
Our primary goal for this line is to resolve it spectrally, to enable us to measure a dynamical mass. A secondary goal is to measure the total line flux, to test the evolution of the [CII]-SFR relation at high redshift. To resolve the line, we assume that we will need detections in three 50 km/s frequency channels. We thus take the total line flux estimate, and divide it by three, to obtain a rough estimate of the expected line flux in these three channels (in practice, the middle channel will be slightly brighter and the two side channels slightly fainter, but as all three are within the FWHM, the flux differences will be ~25%). To robustly measure the line width, we require at least a 4-sigma detection in each of these three channels, so we set our desired sensitivity to 0.2425 mJy (2.91 mJy / 3 channels / 4 [sigma]).
We request an angular resolution of 0.5", larger than the observed UV size of this object; this will keep the object unresolved, but will ensure no confusion with neighboring sources (particularly important for the continuum observations). The total integration time needed to reach our desired limiting sensitivity is 1.51 hr. With overheads and system-defined calibrations, the total requested time for this science goal is 3.14 hr. We note that the line will be detected at 12-sigma significance when averaging over the full ine (e.g., 150 km/s).
Our total continuum sensitivity across the aggregate bandwidth is 0.02 mJy at ~160um rest-frame, which will be sufficient to detect obscured star-formation at >=3 Msol/yr, much less than the expected obscured SFR from this galaxy (~14 Msol/yr).

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: CO(5-4) at z=5.8
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: CO(5-4) emission from a z~5.8 galaxy

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
In this science goal, we propose observations of CO(5-4) emission from a galaxy with a spectroscopic redshift of z=5.79. We center the lowest baseband in the upper sideband on the expected frequency of CO(5-4) (85 GHz; the baseband center is shifted to slightly higher frequency; 0.2 GHz, than the line, to keep the entire baseband within Band 3), and place the other three basebands spanning higher frequencies, to probe the rest-frame far-infrared emission (87, 97 and 99 GHz, which spans rest-frame 450-500 um). In the immediate objective portion of the proposal, we discussed how we arrived at our expected CO(5-4) flux density of 0.56 mJy, assuming a line FWHM of 150 km/s.
For the baseband with the CO emission line, we use the 1.875 GHz bandwidth - this provides the most extra bandwidth for measuring the continuum, but also leaves open the possibility of resolving the line if it is brighter than predicted (the 1.875 GHz bandwidth resolution is ~3 km/s at this frequency, versus 100 km/s for the 2 GHz bandwidth). For the other three basebands, we use the widest bandwidth (2 GHz) setting, as we wish to probe as much of the continuum as possible. We assume a point source, as these galaxies have sizes of ~0.2-0.3".
Our primary goal for this line is to measure the total line flux, to obtain an estimate of the gas mass assuming a local value of alpha, as well as to derive alpha by comparing the CO line flux to the gas mass derived from the dynamical mass from the resolve [CII] observations. We thus assume a sensitivity over a single 150 km/s channel of 0.112 mJy; this will provide a 5-sigma significance detection of the expected line flux.
We request an angular resolution of 0.5", larger than the observed UV sizes of this object; this will keep the object unresolved, but will ensure no confusion with neighboring sources (particularly important for the continuum observations). The total integration time needed to reach our desired limiting sensitivity is 2.30 hr. With overheads and system-defined calibrations, the total requested time for this science goal is 4.13 hr.
Our total continuum sensitivity across the aggregate bandwidth is 0.01 mJy at ~475um rest-frame, which will be sufficient to detect obscured star-formation at >=15 Msol/yr (comparable to the expected obscured SFR from this galaxy, ~14 Msol/yr).

In this science goal, we propose observations of [CII] 158um emission from a galaxy with a spectroscopic redshift of z=4.43. We center the highest baseband in the upper sideband on the expected frequency of [CII] (350 GHz), and place the other three basebands spanning lower frequencies, to probe the rest-frame far-infrared emission (348, 338, 336 GHz, which spans rest-frame 158-164 um). While ideally we would place the continuum sidebands at higher frequency, closer to the peak of dust emission, that lies in a region of strong atmospheric absorption. In the immediate objective portion of the proposal, we discussed how we arrived at our expected [CII] flux density of 5.06 mJy, assuming a line FWHM of 150 km/s.
We use the 1.875 GHz bandwidth for the baseband observing [CII], and the widest bandwidth (2 GHz) setting for the continuum basebands, to probe as much of the continuum as possible. We assume a point source, as these galaxies have sizes of ~0.2-0.3".
Our primary goal for this line is to resolve it spectrally, to enable us to measure a dynamical mass. A secondary goal is to measure the total line flux, to test the evolution of the [CII]-SFR relation at high redshift. To resolve the line, we assume that we will need detections in three 50 km/s frequency channels. We thus take the total line flux estimate, and divide it by three, to obtain a rough estimate of the expected line flux in these three channels (in practice, the middle channel will be slightly brighter and the two side channels slightly fainter, but as all three are within the FWHM, the flux differences will be ~25%). To robustly measure the line width, we require at least a 4-sigma detection in each of these three channels, so we set our desired sensitivity to 0.42167 mJy (5.06 mJy / 3 channels / 4 [sigma]).
We request an angular resolution of 0.5", larger than the observed UV size of this object; this will keep the object unresolved, but will ensure no confusion with neighboring sources (particularly important for the continuum observations). The total integration time needed to reach our desired limiting sensitivity is 37 min. With overheads and system-defined calibrations, the total requested time for this science goal is 1.38 hr. We note that the line will be detected at 12-sigma significance when averaging over the full ine (e.g., 150 km/s).
Our total continuum sensitivity across the aggregate bandwidth is 0.04 mJy at ~160um rest-frame, which will be sufficient to detect obscured star-formation at <=4 Msol/yr (much less than the expected obscured SFR from this galaxy, 22 Msol/yr).

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: CO(4-3) at z=4.4
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: CO(4-3) emission from a z~4.4 galaxy

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
In this science goal, we propose observations of CO(4-3) emission from a galaxy with a spectroscopic redshift of z=4.43. We center the lowest baseband in the upper sideband on the expected frequency of CO(4-3) (85 GHz; the baseband center is shifted to slightly higher frequency; 0.1 GHz, than the line, to keep the entire baseband within Band 3), and place the other three basebands spanning higher frequencies, to probe the rest-frame far-infrared emission (87, 97 and 99 GHz, which spans rest-frame 560-640 um). In the immediate objective portion of the proposal, we discussed how we arrived at our expected CO(4-3) flux density of 0.60 mJy, assuming a line FWHM of 150 km/s.
For the baseband with the CO emission line, we use the 1.875 GHz bandwidth - this provides the most extra bandwidth for measuring the continuum, but also leaves open the possibility of resolving the line if it is brighter than predicted (the 1.875 GHz bandwidth resolution is ~3 km/s at this frequency, versus 100 km/s for the 2 GHz bandwidth). For the other three basebands, we use the widest bandwidth (2 GHz) setting, as we wish to probe as much of the continuum as possible. We assume a point source, as these galaxies have sizes of ~0.2-0.3".
Our primary goal for this line is to measure the total line flux, to obtain an estimate of the gas mass assuming a local value of alpha, as well as to derive alpha by comparing the CO line flux to the gas mass derived from the dynamical mass from the resolve [CII] observations. We thus assume a sensitivity over a single 150 km/s channel of 0.12 mJy; this will provide a 5-sigma significance detection of the expected line flux.
We request an angular resolution of 0.5", larger than the observed UV size of this object; this will keep the object unresolved, but will ensure no confusion with neighboring sources (particularly important for the continuum observations). The total integration time needed to reach our desired limiting sensitivity is 2.01 hr. With overheads and system-defined calibrations, the total requested time for this science goal is 3.82 hr.
Our total continuum sensitivity across the aggregate bandwidth is 0.01 mJy at ~600um rest-frame, which will be sufficient to detect obscured star-formation at <=19 Msol/yr (comparable to the expected obscured SFR from this galaxy, 22 Msol/yr).

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: We request 12.5 hours of ALMA Band 3 and 6 observations to measure CO and [CII] emission lines from two galaxies spectroscopically confirmed to reside at z=4.43 and z=5.79. These observations will provide the first constraints on the gas masses (and gas fractions) in normal (i.e., Milky-Way progenitor) star-forming galaxies at high-redshift, which is the biggest missing measurement to understand galaxy formation. These observations will allow us to constrain their gas-mass fractions, making a simple test of galaxy formation theory. For both galaxies, we will measure one CO transition, and resolve [CII] emission to measure the dynamical mass. Combining these observations will allow us to measure the gas mass, derive the scaling factor “alpha” between gas mass and CO emission at high redshift, and study the star-formation efficiency by comparing the gas mass to the total star-formation rate. Although this is a small, focused, survey, in the coming year we are leading the effort to compile large samples of spectroscopically confirmed galaxies at 4 < z < 7, and the knowledge gained here will enable future full-ALMA programs to target these larger samples of spectroscopic galaxies.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:scientificCategoryString: Cosmology and the High Redshift Universe
